channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Are we all doomed? How to cope with the daunting uncertainties of climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00790-6

It’s easy to feel overwhelmed when thinking about the damage that might be wrought by global warming — but that is missing the point.
item.dc:title: Are we all doomed? How to cope with the daunting uncertainties of climate change
item.dc:creator: Adam Sobel

item.title: Four years on: the career costs for scientists battling long COVID
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00819-w

Many with the condition have found ways around their health problems, but they say more employer support is needed.
item.dc:title: Four years on: the career costs for scientists battling long COVID
item.dc:creator: Shi En Kim

item.title: Verbose robots, and why some people love Bach: Books in Brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00813-2

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Verbose robots, and why some people love Bach: Books in Brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Bird-flu threat disrupts Antarctic penguin studies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00807-0

Projects have been cancelled in an effort to curb the virus’s spread.
item.dc:title: Bird-flu threat disrupts Antarctic penguin studies
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: China’s giant underground neutrino lab prepares to probe cosmic mysteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00694-5

Due to come online this year, the JUNO facility will help to determine which type of neutrino has the highest mass — one of the biggest mysteries in physics.
item.dc:title: China’s giant underground neutrino lab prepares to probe cosmic mysteries
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: People, passion, publishable: an early-career researcher’s checklist for prioritizing projects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00812-3

Stuck between several lines of research? Here’s how we decide which ones to pursue, say Elizabeth Tenney, Jacqueline Chen and McKenzie Preston.
item.dc:title: People, passion, publishable: an early-career researcher’s checklist for prioritizing projects
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Tenney
Jacqueline M. Chen
McKenzie Preston

item.title: Divas, captains, ghosts, ants and bumble-bees: collaborator attitudes explained
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00808-z

Olga Lehmann made sense of challenges she faced in teamwork by analysing how she and her colleagues behaved and what she could have done differently.
item.dc:title: Divas, captains, ghosts, ants and bumble-bees: collaborator attitudes explained
item.dc:creator: Olga Lehmann

item.title: A year in the life: what I learnt from using a time-tracking spreadsheet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00806-1

A low-tech solution helped Megan Rogers to increase her productivity and maintain a good work–life balance.
item.dc:title: A year in the life: what I learnt from using a time-tracking spreadsheet
item.dc:creator: Megan Rogers

item.title: First US drug approved for a liver disease surging around the world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00747-9

A therapy called resmetirom improves hallmarks of an obesity-linked condition that can lead to liver failure.
item.dc:title: First US drug approved for a liver disease surging around the world
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Publisher Correction: Durable CO<sub>2</sub> conversion in the proton-exchange membrane system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07289-0

Publisher Correction: Durable CO2 conversion in the proton-exchange membrane system
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Durable CO<sub>2</sub> conversion in the proton-exchange membrane system

item.title: A fundamental constant in physics gets an update
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00732-2

Scientists controlled a hydrogen atom with electric fields to derive a highly precise estimate of the Rydberg constant.
item.dc:title: A fundamental constant in physics gets an update

item.title: Ditching ‘Anthropocene’: why ecologists say the term still matters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00786-2

Beyond stratigraphic definitions, the name has broader significance for understanding humans’ place on Earth.
item.dc:title: Ditching ‘Anthropocene’: why ecologists say the term still matters
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: A Black mathematical history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00798-y

Documentary reveals how Black US scholars shaped today’s mathematics community and provides hope for the future.
item.dc:title: A Black mathematical history
item.dc:creator: Noelle Sawyer

item.title: More than 4,000 plastic chemicals are hazardous, report finds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00805-2

Year-long effort compiles comprehensive database of chemicals in plastics.
item.dc:title: More than 4,000 plastic chemicals are hazardous, report finds
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: The neuroscientist formerly known as Prince’s audio engineer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00791-5

Susan Rogers worked with the legendary singer-songwriter before earning a PhD in her 50s on auditory memory and how we listen to music throughout life.
item.dc:title: The neuroscientist formerly known as Prince’s audio engineer
item.dc:creator: Anne Gulland

item.title: Do black holes explode? The 50-year-old puzzle that challenges quantum physics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00768-4

Stephen Hawking’s paradoxical finding that black holes don’t live forever has profound, unresolved implications for the quest for unifying theories of reality.
item.dc:title: Do black holes explode? The 50-year-old puzzle that challenges quantum physics
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Fungal diseases are spreading undetected
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00751-z

Low- and middle-income countries are grappling with widespread shortages of diagnostic tests for infections that kill millions.
item.dc:title: Fungal diseases are spreading undetected
item.dc:creator: Charles Schmidt

item.title: Daily briefing: How Hawking’s paradox still puzzles physicists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00811-4

On the sixth anniversary of Stephen Hawking’s death, we revisit his landmark paper. Plus, a stunning 3D atlas of the heart and the mysterious rise of cancer in young people.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How Hawking’s paradox still puzzles physicists
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Publisher Correction: Anti-TIGIT antibody improves PD-L1 blockade through myeloid and T<sub>reg</sub> cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07280-9

Publisher Correction: Anti-TIGIT antibody improves PD-L1 blockade through myeloid and Treg cells
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Anti-TIGIT antibody improves PD-L1 blockade through myeloid and T<sub>reg</sub> cells

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07281-8

Publisher Correction: Nuclear export of circular RNA
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Nuclear export of circular RNA

item.title: Building a heart atlas: researchers map organ in stunning detail
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00775-5

Cutting edge imaging techniques reveal how cells organise as the heart develops.
item.dc:title: Building a heart atlas: researchers map organ in stunning detail
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Pooling babies’ saliva helps catch grave infection in newborns
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00733-1

Cost-saving strategy increases early detection of congenital cytomegalovirus, which can cause developmental problems if left untreated.
item.dc:title: Pooling babies’ saliva helps catch grave infection in newborns

item.title: These cyborg jellyfish could monitor the changing seas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00731-3

A hat-like prosthesis helps the invertebrates to swim more efficiently and can be used to carry ocean sensors.
item.dc:title: These cyborg jellyfish could monitor the changing seas

item.title: Couple-close construction of polycyclic rings from diradicals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07181-x

A couple-close approach used to build semisaturated ring systems from dual radical precursors allows sampling of regions of underexplored chemical space, leading to an annulation that can be used for late-stage functionalization of pharmaceutical scaffolds.
item.dc:title: Couple-close construction of polycyclic rings from diradicals
item.dc:creator: Alice Long
Christian J. Oswood
Christopher B. Kelly
Marian C. Bryan
David W. C. MacMillan

item.title: Neural and behavioural state switching during hippocampal dentate spikes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07192-8

The hippocampal dentate spike, an understudied population event that frequently occurs between sharp-wave ripples, may underlie a mechanism re-engaging the brain with the external world during synchronous population events, and support memory during non-locomotor behaviour.
item.dc:title: Neural and behavioural state switching during hippocampal dentate spikes
item.dc:creator: Jordan S. Farrell
Ernie Hwaun
Barna Dudok
Ivan Soltesz

item.title: US oil and gas system emissions from nearly one million aerial site measurements
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07117-5

We integrate approximately one million aerial site measurements into regional emissions inventories for six regions in the USA, finding methane emission intensities that vary by more than a factor of ten.
item.dc:title: US oil and gas system emissions from nearly one million aerial site measurements
item.dc:creator: Evan D. Sherwin
Jeffrey S. Rutherford
Zhan Zhang

item.title: AIRE relies on Z-DNA to flag gene targets for thymic T cell tolerization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07169-7

Z-DNA anchors the AIRE-mediated transcriptional program by enhancing the generation of double-stranded breaks and promoter poising.
item.dc:title: AIRE relies on Z-DNA to flag gene targets for thymic T cell tolerization
item.dc:creator: Yuan Fang
Kushagra Bansal
Sara Mostafavi
Christophe Benoist
Diane Mathis

item.title: Blueprinting extendable nanomaterials with standardized protein blocks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07188-4

A study describes an approach using designed building blocks that are far more regular in geometry than natural proteins to construct modular multicomponent protein assemblies.
item.dc:title: Blueprinting extendable nanomaterials with standardized protein blocks

item.title: Spatially organized cellular communities form the developing human heart
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07171-z

Combining single-cell RNA-sequencing with high-resolution multiplexed error-robust fluorescence in situ hybridization reveals in detail the cellular interactions and specialization of cardiac cell types that form and remodel the human heart.
item.dc:title: Spatially organized cellular communities form the developing human heart
item.dc:creator: Elie N. Farah

item.title: High-speed and large-scale intrinsically stretchable integrated circuits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07096-7

High-density, intrinsically stretchable transistors with high driving ability and integrated circuits with high operation speed and large-scale integration were enabled by a combination of innovations in materials, fabrication process design, device engineering and circuit design.
item.dc:title: High-speed and large-scale intrinsically stretchable integrated circuits
item.dc:creator: Donglai Zhong

item.title: Substrate-induced condensation activates plant TIR domain proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07183-9

Binding of the substrates NAD+ and ATP to the plant Toll/interleukin-1 receptor (TIR) domain proteins induces phase separation and, thereby, activation of TIR enzymatic and immune signalling activity.
item.dc:title: Substrate-induced condensation activates plant TIR domain proteins
item.dc:creator: Wen Song
Li Liu
Dongli Yu
Hanna Bernardy
Jan Jirschitzka

item.title: Drought triggers and sustains overnight fires in North America
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07028-5

By examining the hourly diurnal cycle of 23,557 fires in North America during 2017–2020, 1,095 overnight burning events were identified, mostly associated with extreme fires and driven by long-term drought conditions.
item.dc:title: Drought triggers and sustains overnight fires in North America
item.dc:creator: Kaiwei Luo
Xianli Wang
Mark de Jong
Mike Flannigan

item.title: Dopamine receptor D2 confers colonization resistance via microbial metabolites
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07179-5

In a mouse model of enteric pathogen infection, tryptophan metabolites protect against infection via activation of dopamine receptor D2 and regulation of actin cytoskeletal organization in intestinal epithelial cells.
item.dc:title: Dopamine receptor D2 confers colonization resistance via microbial metabolites
item.dc:creator: Samantha A. Scott
Jingjing Fu
Pamela V. Chang

item.title: Time-resolved cryo-EM of G-protein activation by a GPCR
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07153-1

Time-resolved cryo-EM is used to capture structural transitions during G-protein activation stimulated by a G-protein-coupled receptor.
item.dc:title: Time-resolved cryo-EM of G-protein activation by a GPCR
item.dc:creator: Makaía M. Papasergi-Scott

item.title: Mitochondrial complex I activity in microglia sustains neuroinflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07167-9

Blocking mitochondrial complex I in pro-inflammatory microglia protects the central nervous system against neurotoxic damage and improves functional outcomes in vivo in an animal disease model.
item.dc:title: Mitochondrial complex I activity in microglia sustains neuroinflammation
item.dc:creator: L. Peruzzotti-Jametti

item.title: Last-mile delivery increases vaccine uptake in Sierra Leone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07158-w

A cluster randomized controlled trial in Sierra Leone shows that targeting access to vaccines in remote areas increases uptake, an approach that can be used to improve vaccine equity in developing countries.
item.dc:title: Last-mile delivery increases vaccine uptake in Sierra Leone
item.dc:creator: Niccolò F. Meriggi
Maarten Voors

item.title: Roll-to-roll, high-resolution 3D printing of shape-specific particles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07061-4

We introduce a scalable, high-resolution, 3D printing technique for the fabrication of shape-specific particles based on roll-to-roll continuous liquid interface production, enabling direct integration within biomedical, analytical and advanced materials applications.
item.dc:title: Roll-to-roll, high-resolution 3D printing of shape-specific particles
item.dc:creator: Jason M. Kronenfeld
Lukas Rother
Max A. Saccone
Maria T. Dulay
Joseph M. DeSimone

item.title: Rapid unleashing of macrophage efferocytic capacity via transcriptional pause release
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07172-y

Macrophages are revealed to adopt a polymerase II pause/release process to effectively deal with ingested apoptotic corpses and for continuous efferocytosis.
item.dc:title: Rapid unleashing of macrophage efferocytic capacity via transcriptional pause release
item.dc:creator: Turan Tufan

item.title: Evolutionary trajectories of small cell lung cancer under therapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07177-7

We uncover key processes of the genomic evolution of small cell lung cancer under therapy, identify the common ancestor as the source of clonal diversity at relapse and show central genomic patterns associated with drug response.
item.dc:title: Evolutionary trajectories of small cell lung cancer under therapy

item.title: Penning micro-trap for quantum computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07111-x

A micro-fabricated Penning trap that operates at a 3 T magnetic field demonstrates full quantum control of an ion and the ability to transport the ion arbitrarily in the trapping plane above the chip.
item.dc:title: Penning micro-trap for quantum computing
item.dc:creator: Shreyans Jain
Tobias Sägesser
Pavel Hrmo

Jonathan Home

item.title: Global supply chains amplify economic costs of future extreme heat risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07147-z

A global high-resolution disaster footprint analytical model is developed to show substantial socioeconomic impacts from climatic change-driven heat stress through the global supply chain by 2060 due to direct and indirect effects on health and labour productivity.
item.dc:title: Global supply chains amplify economic costs of future extreme heat risk
item.dc:creator: Yida Sun
Shupeng Zhu

Shu Tao
Dabo Guan

item.title: The evolution of menopause in toothed whales
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07159-9

A comparative analysis tests competing evolutionary hypotheses in toothed whales in which menopause has evolved many times as females extended their overall lifespan but not their reproductive lifespan, increasing their opportunity for intergenerational help without increasing intergenerational reproductive competition.
item.dc:title: The evolution of menopause in toothed whales
item.dc:creator: Samuel Ellis
Daniel W. Franks
Mia Lybkær Kronborg Nielsen
Michael N. Weiss
Darren P. Croft

item.title: Neural signatures of natural behaviour in socializing macaques
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07178-6

Single-neuron and population activity in the macaque prefrontal and temporal cortex robustly encodes 24 species-typical behaviours, reciprocity in social interactions and social support.
item.dc:title: Neural signatures of natural behaviour in socializing macaques
item.dc:creator: Camille Testard
Sébastien Tremblay
Felipe Parodi
Ron W. DiTullio
Arianna Acevedo-Ithier
Kristin L. Gardiner
Konrad Kording
Michael L. Platt

item.title: Self-enhanced mobility enables vortex pattern formation in living matter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07114-8

We demonstrate that self-enhanced mobility offers a simple physical mechanism for pattern formation in living systems and, more generally, in other active matter systems near the boundary of fluid- and solid-like behaviours.
item.dc:title: Self-enhanced mobility enables vortex pattern formation in living matter
item.dc:creator: Haoran Xu
Yilin Wu

item.title: Anoxygenic phototroph of the Chloroflexota uses a type I reaction centre
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07180-y

Cultivation of a new anoxygenic phototrophic bacterium from Boreal Shield lake water—representing a transition form in the evolution of photosynthesis—offers insights into how the major modes of phototrophy diversified.
item.dc:title: Anoxygenic phototroph of the Chloroflexota uses a type I reaction centre
item.dc:creator: J. M. Tsuji
N. A. Shaw
S. Nagashima

item.title: APOE4/4 is linked to damaging lipid droplets in Alzheimer’s disease microglia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07185-7

A microglial state, featuring lipid droplets and secretion of neurotoxic factors, is shown to be most prominent in people with Alzheimer’s disease who have the APOE4 genotype.
item.dc:title: APOE4/4 is linked to damaging lipid droplets in Alzheimer’s disease microglia

item.title: Chatbot AI makes racist judgements on the basis of dialect
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00779-1

Some large language models harbour hidden biases that cannot be removed using standard methods.
item.dc:title: Chatbot AI makes racist judgements on the basis of dialect
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Drought-fuelled overnight burning propels large fires in North America
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00536-4

Burning events that occur at night have been revealed as a driver of large wildfires. Prolonged drought conditions are to blame, making it easier for fires to spread at night when they would ordinarily slow or extinguish completely.
item.dc:title: Drought-fuelled overnight burning propels large fires in North America
item.dc:creator: Jennifer K. Balch
Adam L. Mahood

item.title: Plutopalooza
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00748-8

It’s the end of the world as we know it.
item.dc:title: Plutopalooza
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Tessmer

item.title: Mobile delivery of COVID-19 vaccines improved uptake in rural Sierra Leone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03186-0

A trial that took mobile health services to rural Sierra Leone finds that this initiative increased COVID-19 vaccine uptake. But more must be done to expand the coverage of health services in low-income countries.
item.dc:title: Mobile delivery of COVID-19 vaccines improved uptake in rural Sierra Leone
item.dc:creator: Alison Buttenheim
Harsha Thirumurthy

item.title: Numbers highlight US dominance in clinical research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00755-9

Institutions from the country make unrivaled contributions to high-quality health-sciences research in the Nature Index.
item.dc:title: Numbers highlight US dominance in clinical research

item.title: Did ‘alien’ debris hit Earth? Startling claim sparks row at scientific meeting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00774-6

Astrophysicist Avi Loeb says that an interstellar meteor showered Earth with particles. At a planetary-science conference this week, researchers begged to differ.
item.dc:title: Did ‘alien’ debris hit Earth? Startling claim sparks row at scientific meeting
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Three actions PhD-holders should take to land their next job
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00727-z

A hiring manager reveals the lessons he learnt when transitioning from a PhD programme to industry.
item.dc:title: Three actions PhD-holders should take to land their next job
item.dc:creator: Fawzi Abou-Chahine

item.title: How AI is being used to accelerate clinical trials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00753-x

From study design to patient recruitment, researchers are investigating ways that technology could speed up the process.
item.dc:title: How AI is being used to accelerate clinical trials
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00758-6

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: Peer-replication model aims to address science’s ‘reproducibility crisis’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00796-0

Researchers propose that independent attempts to replicate results should complement conventional peer review.
item.dc:title: Peer-replication model aims to address science’s ‘reproducibility crisis’
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: Daily briefing: In most mammal species, males and females are the same size — or females are bigger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00800-7

Charles Darwin’s claim about male mammals usually being bigger than females is proved wrong. Plus, OpenAI’s Sora can create amazing video from text prompts, and what’s wrong with how we treat the menopause.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: In most mammal species, males and females are the same size — or females are bigger
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why are so many young people getting cancer? What the data say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00720-6

Clues to a modern mystery could be lurking in information collected generations ago.
item.dc:title: Why are so many young people getting cancer? What the data say
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Ancient malaria genome from Roman skeleton hints at disease’s history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00772-8

Genetic information from ancient remains is helping to reveal how malaria has moved and evolved alongside people.
item.dc:title: Ancient malaria genome from Roman skeleton hints at disease’s history
item.dc:creator: Tosin Thompson

item.title: Deadly brain cancer shrinks after CAR-T therapy — but for how long is unclear
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00704-6

Early studies with engineered immune cells show drastic but often short-lived results in glioblastoma, the most aggressive brain cancer.
item.dc:title: Deadly brain cancer shrinks after CAR-T therapy — but for how long is unclear
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Researchers call for a major rethink of how Alzheimer’s treatments are evaluated
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00756-8

An approach that aims to quantify how long a drug can delay or halt the progression of disease is gathering steam.
item.dc:title: Researchers call for a major rethink of how Alzheimer’s treatments are evaluated
item.dc:creator: Esther Landhuis

item.title: 3D printing enables mass production of microcomponents
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00492-z

Combining a high-throughput technique with 3D printing offers a way of fabricating micrometre-sized particles for use in electronics and biotechnology. The versatile method can produce one million intricate shapes in a single day.
item.dc:title: 3D printing enables mass production of microcomponents
item.dc:creator: Christoph A. Spiegel
Eva Blasco

item.title: Killer whales have menopause. Now scientists think they know why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00794-2

Data suggest menopause evolved to enable older female whales to help younger generations survive, and how researchers made a cellular map of the developing human heart.
item.dc:title: Killer whales have menopause. Now scientists think they know why
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Massive public-health experiment sends vaccination rates soaring
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00730-4

The rate of vaccination against COVID-19 rose sharply in villages in Sierra Leone where health officials held mobile vaccination clinics.
item.dc:title: Massive public-health experiment sends vaccination rates soaring
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Anthony Epstein (1921–2024), discoverer of virus causing cancer in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00763-9

Pathologist whose finding that viruses can trigger tumours in humans transformed medical research.
item.dc:title: Anthony Epstein (1921–2024), discoverer of virus causing cancer in humans
item.dc:creator: Alan Rickinson

item.title: Four change-makers seek impact in medical research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00754-w

Bringing fresh perspectives to long-standing health challenges, these scientists are using techniques such as big-data analytics and AI to push the field.
item.dc:title: Four change-makers seek impact in medical research
item.dc:creator: Amy Coombs
Sandy Ong

item.title: Epstein–Barr virus at 60
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00653-0

The 1964 discovery of Epstein–Barr virus shed light on factors that contribute to human cancer. Subsequent studies set the stage for finding ways to diagnose and treat cancer, and revealed how immune defences control viral infection.
item.dc:title: Epstein–Barr virus at 60
item.dc:creator: Lawrence S. Young

item.title: A spotlight on the stark imbalances of global health research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00752-y

An expansion of the Nature Index to include more than 60 medical journals has revealed the clear leaders in the field.
item.dc:title: A spotlight on the stark imbalances of global health research
item.dc:creator: Bec Crew

item.title: Take these steps to accelerate the path to gender equity in health sciences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00757-7

Without action, parity is still half a century away. We cannot afford to wait that long.
item.dc:title: Take these steps to accelerate the path to gender equity in health sciences
item.dc:creator: Christina Mangurian
Claire D. Brindis

item.title: Whales make waves in the quest to discover why menopause evolved
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00658-9

Why do several species of whale experience menopause, and why does the phenomenon occur at all? Analysing whale data might help to answer these questions and shed light on why menopause evolved in humans.
item.dc:title: Whales make waves in the quest to discover why menopause evolved
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Sear

item.title: Being a parent is a hidden scientific superpower — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00776-4

My lack of time and fresh perspective has made me a better, more focused scientist, says nutrition epidemiologist Lindsey Smith Taillie.
item.dc:title: Being a parent is a hidden scientific superpower — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Lindsey Smith Taillie

Structures and activation mechanism of the Gabija anti-phage system

Nature, Published online: 12 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00760-y

Water shortages means greening southern European cities won’t be easy
